column4: Does anybody know if I can do a file transfer that involves root permission in one step?
sudo cp ?
aaaah .. no. I have /etc/proftpd.conf on my Fedora box, which I want to move to /etc/proftpd.conf on my Ubuntu box. Can I do it in one step?
Are you able to mount the fedora partition in your Ubuntu?
eh? no . I can't. They are on two seperate networks not easily accessible except through ssh.
You can do it via ssh with scp
then I would need two steps..
If you are at the Ubuntu box: scp user@host:/path/to/file /path/to/target (where target is a /path/file on the Ubuntu box)
yeah but what is the /path/to/target on the Ubuntu box is in /etc ???
scp = secure copy, you only need on step if using scp
no. I will have to first copy as a regular user into somewhere in my home directory then use sudo cp to move it into my /etc.
You can "target" anywhere and then just cp to the proper dir, or you can scp blah blah /etc
ok never mind. I will just enable my root account. Sorry for troubling you :)
It's not a good idea to enable the root account.. this can be done without the root account being enabled.
why is it not a good idea to enable root account?

yeah yeah I know the routine. just that I am a long time Linux user, and like to do things the traditional way. Now if enabling root account breaks Ubuntu in anyway that's a pain. But if you are only mentioning so for security reasons and such, I am fine, no problem.
Yeah, I was mentioning it for security reasons and also because enabling the root account is not supported :)
supported by what? You mean if I have the Canonical official support and I enable root account canonical won't support?
If you're a long time Linux user, you should be able to do it without the root account ;)
yes, there are plenty of ways it can be done without root. I could do --> sudo sh -c "scp remote:file local:file" for starters
Yes, and then sudo cp or sudo mv
